Situation1: Laundry needs to be done so clean clothes are available for the family’s activities.
Expectation2: Fix bugs and troubleshoot issues reported by users or QA
Situation2: A minor UI glitch occasionally shows up but has an easy workaround
Story: It’s 7:30 p.m. and I’m staring at the laundry basket, overflowing with clothes that should have been washed yesterday. My husband just reminded me that our daughter needs her soccer uniform clean for tomorrow, and I promised I’d take care of it. At the same time, my phone buzzes with a Slack notification—QA has flagged a minor UI glitch that’s been popping up for some users. It’s not critical, but my manager expects quick turnarounds, and I know I could fix it in half an hour if I just sit down at my laptop. I feel the weight of both roles pressing in: the expectation to keep our home running smoothly, to be a reliable partner, and the unspoken pressure to be the responsive, dependable developer my team counts on. My mind races, torn between the hum of the washing machine and the glow of my screen, knowing that whichever I choose, I’ll be letting someone down.
